description: From Middle English curiosite, variant of curiouste, from Anglo-Norman curiouseté, from Latin cūriōsitātem, accusative of cūriōsitās. Surface analysis curious +‎ -ity. Displaced native Old English firwitt.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Inquisitiveness; the tendency to ask and learn about things by asking questions, investigating, or exploring. [from 17th c.]
A unique or extraordinary object which arouses interest. [from 17th c.]
examples: He put the strangely shaped rock in his curiosity cabinet.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Careful, delicate construction; fine workmanship, delicacy of building. [16th–19th c.]
examples: wee built a homely thing like a barne, set upon Cratchets, covered with rafts, sedge, and earth, so also was the walls; the best of our houses of the like curiosity, but the most part farre much worse workmanship  […]
